actions.text: Mr. McDade reserved all points of order against the bill.
The House Committee on Appropriations reported an original measure, H. Rept. 102-518, by Mr. Whitten.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 306.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 454 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 5132 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit. All points of order against the bill and against its consideration for failure to comply with the provisions of clause 2(l)(6) of rule XI and with clauses 2 and 7 of rule XXI are waived. Measure will be read by section. Amendments are not permitted unless the Chairman yields for such a purpose.
Rule H. Res. 454 passed House.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 454.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 5132 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit. All points of order against the bill and against its consideration for failure to comply with the provisions of clause 2(l)(6) of rule XI and with clauses 2 and 7 of rule XXI are waived. Measure will be read by section. Amendments are not permitted unless the Chairman yields for such a purpose.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
Mr. Myers moved to recommit with instructions to Appropriations.

DEBATE - The House proceeded with ten minutes of debate on the Myers motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on Appropriations with instructions to report the bill back forwith with an amendment to strike the provisions of the bill appropriating $300 million for Federal Emergency Management Agency Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance grants.
On motion to recommit with instructions Failed by voice vote.
On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 244 - 162 (Roll no. 125).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and read twice and referred to the Committee on Appropriations.
Committee on Appropriations. Ordered to be reported with amendments favorably.
Committee on Appropriations. Reported to Senate by Senator Byrd with amendments. Without written report.
Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 466.
Motion to proceed to consideration of measure agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Measure laid before Senate by unanimous consent.
Amendment SP 1834 proposed by Senator Byrd.
Amendment SP 1834 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1835 proposed by Senator Byrd.
Amendment SP 1835 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1836 proposed by Senator Byrd.
Amendment SP 1836 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1837 proposed by Senator Byrd.
Amendment SP 1837 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1838 proposed by Senator Lautenberg.
Amendment SP 1838 agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 59-40. Record Vote No: 101.
Amendment SP 1839 proposed by Senator Moynihan.
Amendment SP 1839 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1840 proposed by Senator Daschle.
Amendment SP 1841 proposed by Senator Hatfield for Senator Seymour.
Amendment SP 1840 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1841 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1842 proposed by Senator Hatfield.
Amendment SP 1842 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1843 proposed by Senator Lieberman.
Amendment SP 1843 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1844 proposed by Senator Graham.
Amendment SP 1844 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1845 proposed by Senator Wofford.
Amendment SP 1846 proposed by Senator Mack.
Amendment SP 1846 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1847 proposed by Senator Bumpers.
Amendment SP 1847 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1845 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1848 proposed by Senator Seymour.
Amendment SP 1849 proposed by Senator Symms.
Amendment SP 1849 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1850 proposed by Senator Graham.
Amendment SP 1850 not agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 45-52. Record Vote No: 102.
Amendment SP 1851 proposed by Senator Hatfield for Senator Nickles.
Amendment SP 1848 agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 68-28. Record Vote No: 103.
Considered by Senate.
Amendment SP 1851 not agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 36-63. Record Vote No: 105.
Amendment SP 1852 proposed by Senator Lott.
Amendment SP 1853 proposed by Senator Byrd for Senator Dole.
Amendment SP 1853 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1854 proposed by Senator Graham.
Amendment SP 1854 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 1855 proposed by Senator Thurmond.
Point of order raised in Senate with respect to SP 1855.
Amendment SP 1852 not agreed to in Senate by Yea-Nay Vote. 37-62. Record Vote No: 106.
SP 1855 determined non-germane by Yea-Nay Vote. 42-57. Record Vote No: 107.
SP 1855 ruled out of order by the chair.
Amendment SP 1856 proposed by Senator Dole for Senator Seymour.
Amendment SP 1856 agreed to in Senate by Voice Vote.
Passed Senate with amendments by Yea-Nay Vote. 61-36. Record Vote No: 109.

Senate insists on its amendments, asks for a conference, appoints conferees Byrd; Inouye; Hollings; Johnston; Burdick; Leahy; Sasser; DeConcini; Bumpers; Lautenberg; Harkin; Mikulski; Reid; Adams; Fowler; Kerrey; Hatfield; Stevens; Garn; Cochran; Kasten; D'Amato; Rudman; Specter; Domenici; Nickles; Gramm; Bond; Gorton.
Mr. Whitten asked unanimous consent that the House disagree to the Senate amendments, and agree to a conference.
On motion that the House disagree to the Senate amendments, and agree to a conference Agreed to without objection.
Mr. McDade moved that the House instruct conferees.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the motion to instruct the conferees on the part of the House to agree to Senate amendment No. 8, regarding Enterprise Zones.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
On motion that the House instruct conferees Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 372 - 21 (Roll no. 153).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Without objection, the Speaker reserved the right to appoint additional conferees.

The Speaker appointed conferees: Whitten, Natcher, Smith (IA), Yates, Obey, Roybal, Bevill, Murtha, Traxler, Lehman (FL), Dixon, Fazio, Hefner, McDade, Myers, Coughlin, Pursell, Green, Lewis (CA), and Rogers.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Message on House action received in Senate.
Conference held.
Conferees agreed to file conference report.
Conference report H. Rept. 102-577 filed with 9 amendments in disagreement.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 491 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of the conference report to H.R. 5132. Upon the adoption of this resolution, it shall be in order, any rule of the House to the contrary notwithstanding, to consider in the House a indivisible motion: 1) to adopt the conference report on H.R. 5132; 2) to agreed to the motions printed in the joint explanatory statement of the committee of conference to dispose of disagreements reported from conference on Senate amendments numbered 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 12, and 13; and 3) to agree to the motions printed in the report of the Committee on Rules accompanying this resolution to dispose of disagreements reported from
Rule H. Res. 491 passed House.
Mr. Natcher brought up conference report H. Rept. 102-577 and accompanying amendments in disagreement for consideration pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 491.

DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 491, the House proceeded with one hour of debate on Mr. Natcher's motion to agree to the conference report and to the disposition of the amendments in disagreement accompanying said conference report.
The previous question on the motion was ordered pursuant to the rule.
On agreeing to the conference report Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 249 - 168 (Roll no. 206).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion that the House recede and concur in the Senate amendment No. 5 Agreed to without objection.
On motion that the House recede and concur with amendment in the Senate amendments Nos. 1, 2, 3, 7, 9, 11, 12, and 13 Agreed to without objection.
Conference papers: message on House action held at the desk in Senate.
Conference report considered in Senate. By Unanimous Consent.
Senate agreed to conference report by Voice Vote.
Senate agreed to the House amendment to Senate amendments nos. 2, 3, 7, 9, 11, 12, and 13 by Voice Vote.
Amendment SP 2432 proposed by Senator Wellstone.
Proposed amendment SP 2432 withdrawn in Senate.
Senate agreed to the House amendment to Senate amendment No. 1 by Voice Vote.
Cleared for White House.
Presented to President.
Signed by President.
Became Public Law No: 102-302.

official_title: Making dire emergency supplemental appropriations for disaster assistance to meet urgent needs because of calamities such as those which occurred in Los Angeles and Chicago, for the fiscal year ending September 30, 1992, and for other purposes.
short_title: Dire Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act, 1992, for Disaster Assistance To Meet Urgent Needs Because of Calamities Such as Those Which Occurred in Los Angeles and Chicago
subjects: Federal aid to law enforcement agencies

summary.as: House receded and concurred with amendment
summary.text: Dire Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act, 1992, for Disaster Assistance To Meet Urgent Needs Because of Calamities such as Those Which Occurred in Los Angeles and Chicago - Makes dire supplemental appropriations for FY 1992 for: (1) the disaster loans program account and business loans programs account of the Small Business Administration; and (2) the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice; (3) the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) for disaster relief and the disaster assistance direct loan program account; (4) the Employment and Training Administration of the Department of Labor for a summer youth employment and training program; and (5) salaries and expenses of the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center and salaries and expenses of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms of the Department of the Treasury for violent crime task forces and increased costs associated with the Los Angeles riot. Rescinds funds made available to the Department of the Treasury for: (1) the United States Customs Service for Air and Marine interdiction programs; (2) salaries and expenses of the United States Mint; (3) salaries and expenses of the Bureau of the Public Debt; and (4) salaries and expenses of the United States Secret Service. Rescinds funds made available to the Executive Office of the President for salaries and expenses of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. Expresses the sense of the Senate that the Congress should adopt Federal enterprise zone legislation. Exempts the block grant program under the Federal Transit Act from requirements for any non-Federal share, in the same manner as specified in temporary matching fund waiver provisions of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. Allows emergency relief funds to be used on all roads classified as local or rural minor collector. Expresses the sense of the Congress that the President should exercise authority to make emergency designations for rural agricultural disasters, as well as the urban disasters in Chicago and Los Angeles. Provides for the treatment of funds appropriated to a State for the control of outdoor advertising. Prohibits the use of funds under this Act for grants, loans, or other assistance to any person who is convicted of, arrested or subject to pending charges for, committing a riot-related crime in the City or County of Los Angeles between April 29 through May 9, 1992. Requires applicants for aid to certify that they do not fall into such category or are acting on behalf of such persons. Makes funds available to provide humanitarian assistance to Bosnia-Hercegovina.
